      <td>3.000000</td>
      <td>6.750000</td>
      <td>18246.750000</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <th>50%</th>
      <td>7.000000</td>
      <td>15.500000</td>
      <td>23719.000000</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <th>75%</th>
      <td>11.000000</td>
      <td>23.250000</td>
      <td>27258.500000</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <th>max</th>
      <td>25.000000</td>
      <td>35.000000</td>
      <td>38045.000000</td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [8]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sex</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value_counts</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">''</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[8]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>male      38
female    14
Name: sex, dtype: int64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>So, obviously, this is a dataset about a theoretical gender discrimination in university employment problem, and one obvious thing we might want to know here is whether there's a gender disparity by rank: are higher ranking faculty in our dataset more likely to be one gender or another?</p>
<p>One classic exploratory tool to get a sense of whether this is true is known as a <em>crosstab</em>. Basically, that's just a fancy name for a table---we might want to know how many assistant professors there are of each gender, associate professors, etc. That's pretty easy to do in Pandas.</p>
<p>This kind of table is also known as a <em>contingency table</em>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [9]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">crosstab</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sex'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">columns</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'rank'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">margins</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[9]:</div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">
<div>
<style scoped>
    .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type {
        vertical-align: middle;
    }

    .dataframe tbody tr th {
        vertical-align: top;
    }

    .dataframe thead th {
        text-align: right;
    }
</style>
<table border="1" class="dataframe">
  <thead>
    <tr style="text-align: right;">
      <th>rank</th>
      <th>assistant</th>
      <th>associate</th>
      <th>full</th>
      <th>All</th>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <th>sex</th>
      <th></th>
      <th></th>
      <th></th>
      <th></th>
    </tr>
  </thead>
  <tbody>
    <tr>
      <th>female</th>
      <td>8</td>
      <td>2</td>
      <td>4</td>
      <td>14</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <th>male</th>
      <td>10</td>
      <td>12</td>
      <td>16</td>
      <td>38</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <th>All</th>
      <td>18</td>
      <td>14</td>
      <td>20</td>
      <td>52</td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can see right away that there is a gender disparity. More than half of women are at the assistant (lowest) rank, while less than a third of men are there; men are more likely to be full professors (the highest rank) than anything else.  Note that this <strong>isn't evidence of discrimination</strong>---after all, there might be some other reason for this disparity (and if this pattern didn't show up, it wouldn't be evidence of no discrimination).  To get serious evidence, we'll have to look at some of the things that we'll talk about in the statistics part of the course.  Nonetheless, it's always good to get a basic look at your data first.</p>
<p>Another great way to understand what your data is all about is to use visualizations.  For this, we'll make use of the Seaborn library that we loaded up right at the beginning of this lesson.</p>
<p>The first visualization tool in our kit is the <em>histogram</em>.  This allows us to visualize the <em>distribution</em> of a single variable in our data---to see how much of our data takes different kinds of values.  Let's look at a histogram of the salary data in this set. In Seaborn, we do this with the <code>distplot()</code> function (for reasons that are a bit obscure---almost every other library calls it "hist").</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [10]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">distplot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"salary"</span><span class="p">])</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[10]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x118766b00></pre>
</div>

</div>

<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This allows us to see the rough shape of our data.  There are a bunch of salaries, it looks like, between 15,000 and 30,000-ish, and many fewer salaries above that.  (Ignore the line drawn through this plot for now, that's a fancy thing called a "kernel density estimate")</p>
<p>You should always start by looking at histograms of your variables of interest.</p>
<p>One gotcha with histograms is that the <em>bin size</em> makes a big difference.  What a histogram does is chunks our data into groupings, each with the same size, and then makes a bar chart of those groups.  Seaborn has an algorithm that by default usually makes a pretty sensible selection, but it's always good to look at different bin widths---it can make a big difference.</p>
<p>In the existing data, it looks like the default Seaborn algorithm chose 5 bins, which seems sensible, but let's change that and see what happens!</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [11]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">distplot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"salary"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">bins</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[11]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x1188680f0></pre>
</div>

</div>

<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [12]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">distplot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"salary"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">bins</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[12]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x1187654e0></pre>
</div>

</div>

<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [13]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">distplot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"salary"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">bins</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[13]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x118a5bb70></pre>
</div>

</div>

<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [14]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">distplot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"salary"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">bins</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[14]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x118b2afd0></pre>
</div>

</div>

<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Depending on how gnarly your dataset is, you might see very different things at different numbers of bins.  So you should look at many.</p>
<p>Another classic standby is the <em>scatterplot</em> which is how we get a first look at how two different numerical variables relate to one another.  Let's see how years since degree relate to salary.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [15]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatterplot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"years_since_degree"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"salary"</span><span class="p">])</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[15]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x118bfb550></pre>
</div>

</div>

<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In a scatterplot, each observation is a dot, and the location of a dot is determined by its value on the two variables.  So it looks like on the whole, the further out from degree someone is, the higher their salary is. This is as to be expected---obviously, more experienced people get paid more.</p>
<h2 id="Discrete-vs-Continuous-variables">Discrete vs Continuous variables<a class="anchor-link" href="#Discrete-vs-Continuous-variables">¶</a></h2><p>One thing that has been in the background of our lesson thus far is the difference between <em>categorical</em> data, also known as <em>discrete</em> data, and <em>numerical</em> data, also known as "continuous" data.</p>
<p>Discrete data is, loosely speaking, data that takes a fixed number of values in your dataset. For example, in the dataset we're working with, gender only takes female and male, it's a discrete variable. Income, by contrast, is continuous because within its range, it could be anything.  (Of course, strictly speaking, this isn't true, because you can't pay people fractions of a penny, and in our data we only have whole dollars.  But it's close enough---these categories are kind of rough.) You could make salary discrete by putting it in <em>bins</em> --- if we created categories like "under 20,000", "20,000-25,000" and so forth, we could <em>discretize</em> that data.</p>
<p>This matters because different visualizations are more or less appropriate for different kinds of data.  For example, scatterplots where one of the variables is discrete tend to be pretty useless.  Take a look:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [16]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatterplot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"sex"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"salary"</span><span class="p">])</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[16]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x118cd52b0></pre>
</div>

</div>

<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>That tells us something, but it doesn't tell us a whole lot!  The reason is because there just isn't enough variation in the sex variable to let us see meaningful associations with this plot.</p>
<p>So what do you do then?  Well, one neat thing we can do is use color to add a categorical dimensions to a scatterplot.  Check this out:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [17]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatterplot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"years_since_degree"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"salary"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">hue</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"sex"</span><span class="p">])</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[17]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x118d7fc50></pre>
</div>

</div>

<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>That let us look at each datapoint and see the gender label attached to it!  So we can see, for example, that it sort of looks like women are more or less concentrated below men, that is, that at the same number of years since degree, it sort of looks like women tend to be paid less.  (We'll make "sort of looks like" much more precise when we learn about regression.)</p>
<p>Another good classic plot to understand how values of a numeric variable differ by a categorical variable is the boxplot:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [18]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">boxplot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"sex"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"salary"</span><span class="p">])</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[18]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x118e216a0></pre>
</div>

</div>

<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The way to read a boxplot is that the boxes shows the <em>interquartile range</em>, or the middle 50% (i.e., the 25th percentile to the 75th percentile) of the distributions---in this case, of the distributions of salary by gender.  The whiskers (bars) at the ends show the full range of the dataset, except for extreme values ("outliers"), which are shown in dots above and below. The bars in the middle of the boxes represent the mean (average).</p>
<p>Here, we can see that salaries for women, on the whole, tend to clump lower than men, except for one woman who is getting a much higher salary than everyone else.</p>
<p>The histogram, scatterplot, and boxplot are the Big Three for data visualizations---between the three of them and their variations, you can usually get a pretty good feel for the overall shape of your data, before you drill down and do analysis on them.</p>
<p>Let's look at a couple more fancy things.  First, you can squeeze an extra color dimension in boxplots too, and that can help you see things like whether, for example, there's variation in salary by gender across different ranks:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [19]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">boxplot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"rank"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"salary"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">hue</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"sex"</span><span class="p">])</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[19]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x118f2e550></pre>
</div>

</div>

<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The interpretation of that table should be pretty obvious  In lots of ways, this looks worse for the gender equity in this notional department: it looks like higher-ranking women are getting distinctively less well paid than men, with the exeption of that one super-high-paid woman.</p>
<p>Another fancy plot is a violin plot, which is like a boxplot, except that it uses one of those kernel estimators to make it possible to visualize the rough number of data points in a given point on the y-axis scale, and doesn't do the interquartile range and outliers thing.  Here's an example:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [20]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">violinplot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"rank"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"salary"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">hue</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"sex"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">inner</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"stick"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[20]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x119056ac8></pre>
</div>

</div>

<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>As you can see, these look quite different from the boxplots, although they capture the same information.  Note that I used an option to draw lines in the middle of each plot for each datapoint (that was the <code>inner="stick"</code> bit).  There are lots of different options with violin plots, and the intuitions they give you can be a bit sensitive to how you choose those options, so I don't recommend them as a first choice.  For example, this plot might make you think different things about the data:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [21]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">violinplot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"rank"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"salary"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">hue</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"sex"</span><span class="p">],</span>  <span class="n">scale</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"count"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">inner</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"stick"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">scale_hue</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[21]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x119189128></pre>
</div>

</div>

<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>What I did there was scale the sizes of the violins to the number of points in them.  This is probably a bit more honest than the previous one, in terms of seeing where things actually lie.</p>
<p>For our last plot, let's fancy-up a boxplot some too by overlaying the actual points on it. This packs a ton of information in---I just want to show you what we can do with fancy plotting:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [22]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">fancyplot</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">boxplot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"rank"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"salary"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">hue</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"sex"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">palette</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"pastel"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">fancyplot</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">swarmplot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"rank"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"salary"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">hue</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"sex"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">dodge</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">palette</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"dark"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>I encourage you to look at the <a href="https://seaborn.pydata.org/tutorial.html">Seaborn tutorial</a> for more examples of the cool stuff you can do with this library.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
 

</body>

entry.title: Introduction to Programming and Python
entry.summary:
In this first week of the course, we're going to cover some core concepts of computer programming. With this, we will build a foundation to do more interesting things in the coming weeks.

What is Computer Programming?¶

Computers basically just do one thing: they complete very simple operations at astonishing speed.

For example, suppose you wanted to calculate the thousandth number of the Fibonacci Sequence

div.cell {
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  border-radius: 2px;
  box-sizing: border-box;
  -moz-box-sizing: border-box;
  -webkit-box-sizing: border-box;
  border-width: 1px;
  border-style: solid;
  border-color: transparent;
  width: 100%;
  padding: 5px;
  /* This acts as a spacer between cells, that is outside the border */
  margin: 0px;
  outline: none;
  position: relative;
  overflow: visible;
}
div.cell:before {
  position: absolute;
  display: block;
  top: -1px;
  left: -1px;
  width: 5px;
  height: calc(100% +  2px);
  content: '';
  background: transparent;
}
div.cell.jupyter-soft-selected {
  border-left-color: #E3F2FD;
  border-left-width: 1px;
  padding-left: 5px;
  border-right-color: #E3F2FD;
  border-right-width: 1px;
  background: #E3F2FD;
}
@media print {
  div.cell.jupyter-soft-selected {
    border-color: transparent;
  }
}
div.cell.selected,
div.cell.selected.jupyter-soft-selected {

}
div.cell.selected:before,

  left: -1px;

}
@media print {

}
.edit_mode div.cell.selected {

@media print {

  }
}
.prompt {
  /* This needs to be wide enough for 3 digit prompt numbers: In[100]: */
  min-width: 14ex;
  /* This padding is tuned to match the padding on the CodeMirror editor. */
  padding: 0.4em;
  margin: 0px;
  font-family: monospace;
  text-align: right;
  /* This has to match that of the the CodeMirror class line-height below */
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  /* Don't highlight prompt number selection */
  -webkit-touch-callout: none;
  -webkit-user-select: none;
  -khtml-user-select: none;
  -moz-user-select: none;
  -ms-user-select: none;
  user-select: none;
  /* Use default cursor */
  cursor: default;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {
  .prompt {
    text-align: left;
  }
}
div.inner_cell {
  min-width: 0;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  /* Old browsers */
  -webkit-box-flex: 1;
  -moz-box-flex: 1;
  box-flex: 1;
  /* Modern browsers */
  flex: 1;
}
/* input_area and input_prompt must match in top border and margin for alignment */
div.input_area {
  border: 1px solid #cfcfcf;
  border-radius: 2px;
  background: #f7f7f7;
  line-height: 1.21429em;
}
/* This is needed so that empty prompt areas can collapse to zero height when there
   is no content in the output_subarea and the prompt. The main purpose of this is
   to make sure that empty JavaScript output_subareas have no height. */
div.prompt:empty {
  padding-top: 0;
  padding-bottom: 0;
}
div.unrecognized_cell {
  padding: 5px 5px 5px 0px;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: horizontal;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: horizontal;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: horizontal;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: row;
  align-items: stretch;
}
div.unrecognized_cell .inner_cell {
  border-radius: 2px;
  padding: 5px;
  font-weight: bold;
  color: red;
  border: 1px solid #cfcfcf;
  background: #eaeaea;
}
div.unrecognized_cell .inner_cell a {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: none;
}
div.unrecognized_cell .inner_cell a:hover {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: none;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {
  div.unrecognized_cell > div.prompt {
    display: none;
  }
}
div.code_cell {
  /* avoid page breaking on code cells when printing */
}
@media print {
  div.code_cell {
    page-break-inside: avoid;
  }
}
/* any special styling for code cells that are currently running goes here */
div.input {
  page-break-inside: avoid;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: horizontal;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: horizontal;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: horizontal;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: row;
  align-items: stretch;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {
  div.input {
    /* Old browsers */
    display: -webkit-box;
    -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
    -webkit-box-align: stretch;
    display: -moz-box;
    -moz-box-orient: vertical;
    -moz-box-align: stretch;
    display: box;
    box-orient: vertical;
    box-align: stretch;
    /* Modern browsers */
    display: flex;
    flex-direction: column;
    align-items: stretch;
  }
}
/* input_area and input_prompt must match in top border and margin for alignment */
div.input_prompt {
  color: #303F9F;
  border-top: 1px solid transparent;
}
div.input_area > div.highlight {
  margin: 0.4em;
  border: none;
  padding: 0px;
  background-color: transparent;
}
div.input_area > div.highlight > pre {
  margin: 0px;
  border: none;
  padding: 0px;
  background-color: transparent;
}
/* The following gets added to the <head> if it is detected that the user has a
 * monospace font with inconsistent normal/bold/italic height.  See
 * notebookmain.js.  Such fonts will have keywords vertically offset with
 * respect to the rest of the text.  The user should select a better font.
 * See: https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/1503
 *
 * .CodeMirror span {
 *      vertical-align: bottom;
 * }
 */
.CodeMirror {
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  /* Changed from 1em to our global default */
  font-size: 14px;
  height: auto;
  /* Changed to auto to autogrow */
  background: none;
  /* Changed from white to allow our bg to show through */
}
.CodeMirror-scroll {
  /*  The CodeMirror docs are a bit fuzzy on if overflow-y should be hidden or visible.*/
  /*  We have found that if it is visible, vertical scrollbars appear with font size changes.*/
  overflow-y: hidden;
  overflow-x: auto;
}
.CodeMirror-lines {
  /* In CM2, this used to be 0.4em, but in CM3 it went to 4px. We need the em value because */
  /* we have set a different line-height and want this to scale with that. */
  /* Note that this should set vertical padding only, since CodeMirror assumes
       that horizontal padding will be set on CodeMirror pre */
  padding: 0.4em 0;
}
.CodeMirror-linenumber {
  padding: 0 8px 0 4px;
}
.CodeMirror-gutters {
  border-bottom-left-radius: 2px;
  border-top-left-radius: 2px;
}
.CodeMirror pre {
  /* In CM3 this went to 4px from 0 in CM2. This sets horizontal padding only,
    use .CodeMirror-lines for vertical */
  padding: 0 0.4em;
  border: 0;
  border-radius: 0;
}
.CodeMirror-cursor {
  border-left: 1.4px solid black;
}
@media screen and (min-width: 2138px) and (max-width: 4319px) {
  .CodeMirror-cursor {
    border-left: 2px solid black;
  }
}
@media screen and (min-width: 4320px) {
  .CodeMirror-cursor {
    border-left: 4px solid black;
  }
}
/*

Original style from softwaremaniacs.org (c) Ivan Sagalaev <Maniac@SoftwareManiacs.Org>
Adapted from GitHub theme

*/
.highlight-base {
  color: #000;
}
.highlight-variable {
  color: #000;
}
.highlight-variable-2 {
  color: #1a1a1a;
}
.highlight-variable-3 {
  color: #333333;
}
.highlight-string {
  color: #BA2121;
}
.highlight-comment {
  color: #408080;
  font-style: italic;
}
.highlight-number {
  color: #080;
}
.highlight-atom {
  color: #88F;
}
.highlight-keyword {
  color: #008000;
  font-weight: bold;
}
.highlight-builtin {
  color: #008000;
}
.highlight-error {
  color: #f00;
}
.highlight-operator {
  color: #AA22FF;
  font-weight: bold;
}
.highlight-meta {
  color: #AA22FF;
}
/* previously not defined, copying from default codemirror */
.highlight-def {
  color: #00f;
}
.highlight-string-2 {
  color: #f50;
}
.highlight-qualifier {
  color: #555;
}
.highlight-bracket {
  color: #997;
}
.highlight-tag {
  color: #170;
}

div.output_wrapper {
  /* this position must be relative to enable descendents to be absolute within it */
  position: relative;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  z-index: 1;
}
/* class for the output area when it should be height-limited */
div.output_scroll {
  /* ideally, this would be max-height, but FF barfs all over that */
  height: 24em;
  /* FF needs this *and the wrapper* to specify full width, or it will shrinkwrap */
  width: 100%;
  overflow: auto;
  border-radius: 2px;
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);
  box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);
  display: block;
}
/* output div while it is collapsed */
div.output_collapsed {
  margin: 0px;
  padding: 0px;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
}
div.out_prompt_overlay {
  height: 100%;
  padding: 0px 0.4em;
  position: absolute;
  border-radius: 2px;
}
div.out_prompt_overlay:hover {
  /* use inner shadow to get border that is computed the same on WebKit/FF */
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 0 1px #000;
  box-shadow: inset 0 0 1px #000;
  background: rgba(240, 240, 240, 0.5);
}
div.output_prompt {
  color: #D84315;
}
/* This class is the outer container of all output sections. */
div.output_area {
  padding: 0px;
  page-break-inside: avoid;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: horizontal;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: horizontal;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: horizontal;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */

  flex-direction: row;
  align-items: stretch;
}
div.output_area .MathJax_Display {

}

div.output_area svg {

}

div.output_area pre {
  margin: 0;

  border: 0;
  vertical-align: baseline;
  color: black;
  background-color: transparent;
  border-radius: 0;
}
/* This class is for the output subarea inside the output_area and after
   the prompt div. */
div.output_subarea {
  overflow-x: auto;
  padding: 0.4em;
  /* Old browsers */
  -webkit-box-flex: 1;
  -moz-box-flex: 1;
  box-flex: 1;
  /* Modern browsers */

  max-width: calc(100% - 14ex);
}
div.output_scroll div.output_subarea {

}
/* The rest of the output_* classes are for special styling of the different
   output types */
/* all text output has this class: */
div.output_text {
  text-align: left;

  /* This has to match that of the the CodeMirror class line-height below */
  line-height: 1.21429em;
}
/* stdout/stderr are 'text' as well as 'stream', but execute_result/error are *not* streams */

}

}
/* Empty output_javascript divs should have no height */

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In this first week of the course, we're going to cover some core concepts of computer programming. With this, we will build a foundation to do more interesting things in the coming weeks.</p>
<h2 id="What-is-Computer-Programming?">What is Computer Programming?<a class="anchor-link" href="#What-is-Computer-Programming?">¶</a></h2><p>Computers basically just do one thing: they complete very simple operations at astonishing speed.</p>
<p>For example, suppose you wanted to calculate the thousandth number of the <a href="https://www.mathsisfun.com/numbers/fibonacci-sequence.html">Fibonacci Sequence</a> --- the sequence of numbers such that starts with 0 and 1, and then each subsequent number is the sum of the previous two numbers.  For example:</p>
<p>0 1 1 2 3 5 8 13</p>
<p>Don't go on until you are satisfied you know what the next number is.</p>
<p>As you can imagine, it would take a fairly long time to calculate it by hand.  However, a computer can do it in less than a second. I'll show you:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [1]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">digit</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">3</span>
<span class="n">first</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span>
<span class="n">second</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span>
<span class="k">while</span> <span class="n">digit</span> <span class="o"><</span> <span class="mi">1001</span><span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="n">answer</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">first</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">second</span>
    <span class="n">first</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">second</span>
    <span class="n">second</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">answer</span>
    <span class="n">digit</span> <span class="o">+=</span> <span class="mi">1</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"the "</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">digit</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="s2">"th number in the Fibonacci sequence is: "</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">answer</span><span class="p">))</span>
    
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>the 1000th number in the Fibonacci sequence is: 26863810024485359386146727202142923967616609318986952340123175997617981700247881689338369654483356564191827856161443356312976673642210350324634850410377680367334151172899169723197082763985615764450078474174626
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This is obviously not a number you would want to try to compute by hand, or even using a pocket calculator! (Incidentally, if you looked up a list of those numbers and found a different result, try comparing it to the 999th number. People seem to differ on whether to start counting from 0 or 1 in enumerating the Fibonacci sequence.)</p>
<p>Everything that computers do---including the system you're reading this on right now---is built up by doing very simple ("primitive") operations many many times. The way it works is that programmers build those primitives---basic arithmetic operations and pushing things around in memory, basically---into more complicated pieces of functionality. Then the next programmer can use that complicated piece of functionality (often called an "abstraction") and build some of those up into something more complicated, and so on, and so on.</p>
<p>We will start at a much higher level, but you'll learn to do that yourself!</p>
<p>Let's start by breaking down the Fibonacci sequence code above:</p>

<pre><code>digit = 3
first = 0
second = 1
while digit < 1001:
    answer = first + second
    first = second
    second = answer
    digit += 1
print("the " + str(digit - 1) + "th number in the Fibonacci sequence is: " + str(answer))</code></pre>
<p>The first three lines are <strong>variable assignments</strong> --- they give a name to some piece of data. In this case, we've given the name <code>digit</code> to the number 3, and so forth. Once we give a name to some piece of data, we can refer to that name and get back that data---and we can change the data attached to the name as well.</p>
<p>It's good to use descriptive names, so anyone else reading your code (or future you) can tell what you're trying to do.  Here, I used names meant to track exactly what we're doing: the  <code>digit</code> starts at 3 because we start calculating at the third digit of the Fibonacci sequence (we know the first two already). Likewise, <code>first</code> and <code>second</code> represent the two numbers we need to add up to get the third.</p>
<p><code>while digit < 1001:</code></p>
<p>The 4th line starts a <strong>while loop</strong>.  Remember how I said that computers are really good at doing the same thing over and over?  The most basic mechanism for doing so is the loop, which is just programmer-speak for "execute a list of instructions repeatedly."</p>
<p>The structure ("syntax") of the while loop in Python (it's different in other languages) is:</p>
<ol>
<li><p>The keyword <code>while</code> at the start of the line.</p>
</li>
<li><p>An <em>expression</em> evaluating to a <em>boolean</em> after that.  (I'll explain what the italicized terms mean in a moment.)  This is known as the condition.</p>
</li>
<li><p>A colon at the end of the line.</p>
</li>
<li><p>An indented series of lines ("block") containing <em>statements</em>, known as the "body" of the loop.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>The way it works is that each of the statements in the indented block will be executed in sequence so long as the condition is true.</p>
<p>Thus, the English translation of the Python <code>while digit < 1001:</code> is "go look up the value of the <code>digit</code> variable. So long as it is less than 1001, execute all the indented statements  that follow."</p>
<p>Let's talk about some of those vocabulary words.</p>
<p>First, most of what you can write in Python can be divided into expressions and statements. Essentially (and I'm simplifying a bit here), an <strong>expression</strong> is like algebra: it's a representation of some value, and its value can be substituted in for it. For example <code>1 + 1</code> is an expression, and 2 can seamlessly be substituted in for it. We say that an expression <strong>evaluates</strong> to its value: <code>1 + 1</code> evaluates to 2.</p>
<p>In <code>while digit < 1001</code> the <code>digit < 1001</code> part is an expression. It evaluates to a special type of result, known as a <strong>boolean</strong>.  In Python, the two boolean values are <strong>True</strong> and <strong>False</strong> and they mean pretty much what you would expect them to mean. So <code>digit < 1001</code> tells the computer "go look up the value of <code>digit</code> and see if it's less than 1001. If so, replace the value of this expression by <code>True</code>; otherwise, replace it with <code>False</code>.</p>
<p><strong>Statements</strong> can be seen as instructions to the computer. They aren't meant to be evaluated to some value, but are meant to bring something about in the world inside the computer's head. We've seen a lot of statements already: the variable assignments we've looked at are all statements. They don't calculate anything, they just tell the computer "hold onto this name for this quantity."</p>
<p>If we wrote a line like <code>my_sum = 1 + 1</code> we would have an expression and a statement. What happens is that first the expression <code>1 + 1</code> is evaluated to 2, and then that value is assigned to the variable <code>my_sum</code>.  We always read variable assignments right to left: evaluate all the stuff on the right side of the equals sign, and then assign whatever we get out of it to the name on the left side.</p>
<p>Generally, you can have a lot of expressions in a line --- you could say something like <code>weird_quantity = 5 * (9 + 28) * 2015 / 99</code> and that's fine. Generally, you don't have more than one statement in a line.</p>
<p>Sometimes, expressions do something (like statements do) in addition to evaluating to a value. Those are called <em>side-effects</em> but don't worry about that for now.</p>
<p>Ok, let's keep going!  You should be able to figure out what <code>answer = first + second</code> means--- it assigns the variable <code>answer</code> to the expression <code>first + second</code>.  It looks up the values of <code>first</code> and <code>second</code> and sums them. You should see that <code>answer</code> get the value 1.</p>
<p>The next two lines introduce one of the main reasons we use variables. As the name suggests, it's because they can <em>vary</em>.</p>

<pre><code>first = second
second = answer</code></pre>
<p>We're reassigning our variables here!  Remember, we do variable assignment right to left. So what this means is "take the value currently attached to the name <code>second</code> and assign it to <code>first</code>, then take the variable currently attached to the name <code>answer</code> and assign it to <code>second.</code></p>
<p>Think about how this works in terms of the first few digits of the Fibonacci sequence. Consider the following table, where the first row is the digit we're on (first, second, etc.) and the second row is the value:</p>
<table>
<thead><tr>
<th></th>
<th></th>
<th>\/</th>
<th></th>
<th></th>
<th></th>
<th></th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>1</td>
<td>2</td>
<td>3</td>
<td>4</td>
<td>5</td>
<td>6</td>
<td>7</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>0</td>
<td>1</td>
<td>1</td>
<td>2</td>
<td>3</td>
<td>5</td>
<td>8</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>^1</td>
<td>^2</td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Let's imagine an arrow poing to the digit we're trying to sort out. So when we start, the arrow is pointing at 3 (the variable <code>digit</code>), because we're trying to calculate the third digit. We calculate that digit by looking to the first number of the two immediately preceeding numbers (the variable <code>first</code>, represented in the table by ^1), and adding it to the second number of the two immediately preceeding (the variable <code>second</code>, represented in the table by ^2), giving us the total (variable <code>answer</code>).</p>
<p>But we're not done yet, because we still have 997 more numbers to calculate. So how do we calculate the 4th digit?  Well, we need to add the last two digits again... the number that used to be in the variable <code>second</code> is the first digit we'll add the next time, and the current digit (variable <code>answer</code>) is the second one.  In order to tell the computer that's going to happen, we reassign those variables.</p>
<p>The last line of our loop <code>digit += 1</code> is a special syntax for <em>incrementing</em> the value of a variable---it just says "replace the value of <code>digit</code> with its own value plus 1." In our chart above, that just means moving the digit forward.</p>
<p>So, here's a representation of out computer's memory at the start of the indented block:</p>
<table>
<thead><tr>
<th></th>
<th></th>
<th>\/</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>1</td>
<td>2</td>
<td>3</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>0</td>
<td>1</td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>^1</td>
<td>^2</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>And here's a representation of out computer's memory at the end of the indented block:</p>
<table>
<thead><tr>
<th></th>
<th></th>
<th></th>
<th>\/</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>1</td>
<td>2</td>
<td>3</td>
<td>4</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>0</td>
<td>1</td>
<td>1</td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td></td>
<td>^1</td>
<td>^2</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>The arrow indicating what digit we're about to calculate has moved to the 4th place, and the arrows indicating what digits we're going to sum up have moved to the second and third, plus we've added an answer for the latter.</p>
<p>And finally, the magic of loops kicks in. Now that we're at the end of our indented block, the computer jumps back up to the start of the while loop.</p>
<p>First, it checks the condition again. Is <code>digit</code> still less than 1001?  Yes, it is. It's 4 now, instead of 3, but that's lots less than 1001. So now, we go back into the body of the loop, this time using the new values of our variables!</p>
<p>After another iteration of the loop, here's what the computer knows:</p>
<table>
<thead><tr>
<th></th>
<th></th>
<th></th>
<th></th>
<th>\/</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>1</td>
<td>2</td>
<td>3</td>
<td>4</td>
<td>5</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>0</td>
<td>1</td>
<td>1</td>
<td>2</td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td>^1</td>
<td>^2</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>And then it keeps doing that, again and again, moving the arrow up top each time, at blinding speed.</p>
<p>Now let's think of what happens after it calculates the 1000th digit.  Here's where we are:</p>
<table>
<thead><tr>
<th></th>
<th></th>
<th></th>
<th></th>
<th></th>
<th></th>
<th></th>
<th></th>
<th>\/</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>1</td>
<td>2</td>
<td>3</td>
<td>4</td>
<td>5</td>
<td>...</td>
<td>999</td>
<td>1000</td>
<td>1001</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>0</td>
<td>1</td>
<td>1</td>
<td>2</td>
<td>3</td>
<td>...</td>
<td>lots</td>
<td>lots</td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td>...</td>
<td>^1</td>
<td>^2</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>This time, when it goes back to the start of the loop, it tests the condition and finds that it's <code>False</code>. <code>digit</code> isn't under 1001 any more!</p>
<p>So now, it jumps out of the while loop and goes to the next line:</p>
<p><code>print("the " + str(digit - 1) + "th number in the Fibonacci sequence is: " + str(answer))</code></p>
<p>This line calls the <code>print()</code> function, which instructs the computer to print to the screen (not to a paper printer!) the expression inside the parentheses. (We'll talk about functions and what the parentheses do in a little bit.)</p>
<p>The stuff inside the parentheses is a <strong>string</strong>---that is, an piece of text that the computer represents in memory, made up of <strong>characters</strong>.  Typically we tell Python to hold onto a string by surrounding it with quotes (single or double both work, but they have to match). These are called <strong>string literals</strong>. Like:</p>
<p><code>my_sentence = "Hi, I am Gowder's sentence."</code></p>
<p>But you can also create strings out of expressions, and use them in other expressions. One of the neat things that you can do with strings is <strong>concatenate</strong> them, that is, use the plus sign to sort of add them together, so that <code>"the cat " + "in the hat"</code> evaluates to <code>"the cat in the hat"</code>.</p>
<p>So what that last line does is look up the last value that <code>answer</code> got (which is the 1000th digit, because we haven't calculated the 1001th yet), convert that into a string with the <code>str()</code> function (turning it from, e.g., <code>12345</code> into <code>"12345"</code>---this matters!), does the same with <code>digit</code>, and then concatenates them all together with the string literals there into one big string, which we print to the screen so that we can learn the answer to our math puzzle!</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Now-you-try!">Now you try!<a class="anchor-link" href="#Now-you-try!">¶</a></h2><p>We're at the end of our first handout. There are a couple more in this lesson, but, before you go onto the next one, try using a loop to calculate a different quantity!</p>
<p>As you might remember from your early schooling, the factorial of a number, denoted n!, is the product of that number and all the positive integers before it. For example, 5! = 1x2x3x4x5 = 120</p>
<p>In the next cell, use a loop to calculate 1000 factorial.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [ ]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span> 
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
 

</body>
